ground_truth: She looks toward the front of Thorwald's apartment house, and by her attitude, we can see that there is no truck outside. She looks about her for a moment. The figure of Stella is seen, looking up toward Jeff's apartment, and arms outspread in a helpless gesture. Jeff lowers the binoculars, discouraged. He lowers the glasses and turns to Jeff. Shooting towards the big window, with the neighborhood beyond, Jeff is as usual seated in his wheelchair on the left of the window, but now turned toward a newcomer, the second man standing near the divan looking out the window with the binoculars. This newcomer is Police Detective Lieutenant Thomas J. Doyle, the man Jeff phoned earlier in the day. He has a sense of humor. Jeff lifts his hand in a feeble parting gesture. He is an intelligent-appearing, well-dressed modern detective. Doyle paces a little. He goes up the steps to the door, putting on his hat, and pauses his hand on the door knob. From Doyle's viewpoint, Jeff answers, showing only the slightest irritation. Doyle, still at the door, starts to go out the door, and closes it behind him. Doyle becomes interested in watching something out the window: Miss Torso, in ballet costume, practicing her dance on the outside balcony. She is exciting and desirable, and he even smiles somewhat secretly to himself at what he sees. Jeff smiles at catching Doyle enjoying Miss Torso and notices Doyle's interest. Startled at being observed, Doyle moves quickly away from the window, affecting nonchalance. Jeff's face grows serious as Doyle quickly collects his thoughts and gets back to the case at hand. The camera moves back as Doyle returns to his drink, moves to the sideboard, picks up a felt hat, pulls a slip of paper out of his pocket, and Jeff watches him intently. Doyle looks at Jeff with some smugness, puts on his hat, and goes toward the door. The camera concentrates on the long-focus lens camera, which fills the screen. Just beyond, there is a plate on which a solitary sandwich rests. Jeff's hand comes in and picks it up. We pan up with the sandwich until Jeff's head fills the screen. Jeff is sober, and except for a small light in the kitchen, Jeff's apartment is in darkness. As he munches, he keeps his attention on the neighborhood. The camera pans slightly to the left, as we see the dog being lowered in its basket. Thorwald's apartment is in darkness as the sun has just set. We follow the basket down to the yard, which brings Miss Lonely Heart's apartment into view as she seems to be putting on the final touches of her makeup, prior to going out.

Jeff is serious, and except for a small illumination in the kitchen, Jeff's apartment is in shadow. As he chews, he keeps his gaze on the vicinity. The camera pans slightly to the left, as we see the canine being lowered in its basket. Thorwald's apartment is in shadow as the sun has just set. We follow the basket down to the courtyard, which brings Miss Lonely Heart's apartment into view as she seems to be putting on the final touches of her cosmetics, prior to going out.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: She looks toward Thorwald's apartment, revealing no truck outside. She glances around briefly. Stella appears, looking up at Jeff's apartment with a helpless gesture. Discouraged, Jeff lowers the binoculars. At the big window, Jeff, seated in his wheelchair, is turned toward a newcomer: Police Detective Lieutenant Thomas J. Doyle, whom Jeff phoned earlier. Doyle, a humorous and intelligent detective, paces, dons his hat, and pauses at the door. Observing Miss Torso in a ballet outfit practicing on the balcony, Doyle smiles to himself. Jeff notices Doyle's interest and smiles. Startled at being noticed, Doyle moves away from the window, feigning indifference. Jeff grows serious as Doyle regains focus on the case. Returning to his drink, Doyle picks up his hat and a slip of paper, looking at Jeff smugly before leaving. The camera focuses on a long-focus lens camera, with a solitary sandwich nearby. Jeff picks it up, and as he eats, he watches the neighborhood. The camera pans to the left, revealing a dog in its basket and Miss Lonely Heart's apartment as she finishes her makeup, preparing to go out.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: She looks toward Thorwald's apartment, noting no truck outside. Stella appears, gesturing helplessly toward Jeff's apartment. Jeff, discouraged, lowers his binoculars and turns to Police Detective Lieutenant Thomas J. Doyle, sitting near him. The modern detective, whom Jeff called earlier, paces, dons his hat, and pauses at the door. Doyle observes Miss Torso dancing on the balcony, briefly enjoying the view until Jeff catches him, leading Doyle to refocus on the case. Doyle, appearing smug, picks up his hat and a slip of paper, then heads to the door. The camera focuses on a long-focus lens camera as Jeff picks up a sandwich. As he eats, the apartment remains dark except for a kitchen light, and he watches the neighborhood. The dog descends in its basket, revealing Thorwald's darkened apartment at sunset and Miss Lonely Heart's apartment as she finishes her makeup.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: She directs her gaze toward the entrance of Thorwald's apartment house, and from her demeanor, it's evident that there is no truck parked outside. Taking a moment to look around her surroundings, she surveys the scene. At this point, the form of Stella comes into view; she is casting her eyes upward towards Jeff's apartment, with her arms extended in a gesture that conveys helplessness. Feeling disheartened, Jeff lowers the binoculars, having lost some of his initial enthusiasm. He places the glasses down and turns his attention to Jeff. The camera, capturing the expansive scene through the large window with the bustling neighborhood in the background, focuses on Jeff, who is, as is typical, positioned in his wheelchair to the left of the window. His attention, however, is now directed toward a newcomer—another man standing close to the divan, peering out of the window through binoculars. This newcomer is none other than Police Detective Lieutenant Thomas J. Doyle, the very man Jeff had contacted earlier that day. Doyle is known for his sharp sense of humor, adding a unique flair to his persona. Jeff, in a somewhat weak yet acknowledging manner, raises his hand in a parting gesture that speaks of familiarity and respect. Doyle, a modern detective who appears both smart and well-dressed, begins to pace a bit. As he makes his way up the steps leading to the door, he dons his hat and pauses for a brief moment, his hand resting on the doorknob. From Doyle's perspective, Jeff responds with just a hint of irritation, suggesting a level of impatience. Remaining at the door, Doyle initiates his exit, gently closing the door behind him. However, his attention is captured by something outside the window: Miss Torso, clad in a ballet costume, is gracefully practicing her dance on the balcony. She exudes excitement and allure, prompting Doyle to smile to himself, almost secretly, as he observes the scene. Jeff, noticing this moment, smiles too, having caught Doyle in a moment of enjoyment as he watches Miss Torso. Startled at being observed, Doyle swiftly moves away from the window, attempting to appear nonchalant. Jeff’s expression turns serious as Doyle quickly regains his composure and refocuses on the matter at hand. The camera pulls back as Doyle returns to his drink; he moves toward the sideboard, retrieves a felt hat, and pulls a slip of paper from his pocket, all the while being watched intently by Jeff. With a touch of smugness, Doyle glances at Jeff, puts on his hat, and makes his way towards the door. The camera then zeroes in on the long-focus lens camera, which dominates the screen. Just next to it sits a plate, upon which rests a solitary sandwich. Jeff’s hand enters the frame, taking the sandwich. We follow the sandwich upward until Jeff's face fills the screen. He appears thoughtful and serious, his face illuminated only by a small light in the kitchen, while the rest of his apartment is shrouded in darkness. As he chews, he remains focused on observing the neighborhood. The camera gradually pans to the left, capturing the scene of a dog being gently lowered in its basket. Thorwald's apartment is enveloped in darkness since the sun has just set. Our gaze follows the basket as it descends into the yard, seamlessly bringing Miss Lonely Heart's apartment into view, where she seems to be meticulously applying the final touches to her makeup, preparing to go out.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: She carefully directs her gaze toward the entrance of Thorwald's apartment house, and from her demeanor, it becomes evident that there is no truck parked outside as expected. Taking a moment, she looks around her surroundings, thoughtfully surveying the scene before her. At this particular juncture, the familiar form of Stella comes into view; she is casting her eyes upward toward Jeff's apartment, with her arms extended in a gesture that clearly conveys helplessness. Feeling somewhat disheartened, Jeff lowers the powerful binoculars, having lost some of his initial enthusiasm and zeal. He places the glasses down gently and shifts his focus to Jeff. The camera captures the expansive city scene through the large window, with the bustling neighborhood in the background, as it focuses intently on Jeff, who is, as is his custom, positioned in his wheelchair to the left side of the window. His attention, however, is now directed toward a newcomer—another man standing close to the divan who is peering out of the window with binoculars. This newcomer is none other than Police Detective Lieutenant Thomas J. Doyle, the very same man Jeff had reached out to earlier in the day. Doyle is well-known for his sharp sense of humor, which adds a unique flair to his already distinctive persona. Jeff, in an almost weak yet acknowledging manner, raises his hand in a parting gesture that speaks volumes of familiarity and respect. Doyle, a modern detective who appears both smart and well-dressed, begins to pace a bit as he makes his way up the steps leading to the door. He dons his hat and pauses for a brief moment, his hand gently resting on the doorknob. From Doyle's perspective, Jeff responds with just a hint of irritation, subtly suggesting a level of impatience. Remaining at the door, Doyle initiates his exit, gently closing the door behind him. However, his attention is quite unexpectedly captured by something outside the window: Miss Torso, clad in a delicate ballet costume, is gracefully and diligently practicing her dance on the balcony. She exudes an air of excitement and allure, prompting Doyle to smile to himself, almost secretly, as he observes the enchanting scene. Jeff, noticing this brief moment, smiles too, having caught Doyle in a moment of enjoyment as he watches Miss Torso. Startled at being observed in such a way, Doyle swiftly moves away from the window, hastily attempting to appear nonchalant and undistracted. Jeff’s expression turns serious as Doyle quickly regains his composure and refocuses on the matter at hand. The camera pulls back as Doyle returns to his drink; he moves toward the sideboard, retrieves a felt hat, and pulls a slip of paper from his pocket, all the while being watched intently by Jeff. With a touch of smugness, Doyle glances at Jeff, puts on his hat, and purposefully makes his way toward the door. The camera then zeroes in on the long-focus lens camera, which dominates the screen. Just next to it sits a plate, upon which rests a solitary sandwich. Jeff’s hand enters the frame, taking hold of the sandwich. We dutifully follow the sandwich upward until Jeff's face fills the screen. He appears thoughtful and serious, his face illuminated only by a small, dim light in the kitchen, while the rest of his apartment is shrouded in shadows and darkness. As he chews, he remains intensely focused on observing the neighborhood. The camera gradually and smoothly pans to the left, capturing the serene scene of a dog being gently lowered in its basket. Thorwald's apartment is enveloped in darkness since the sun has just set. Our gaze follows the basket as it descends gracefully into the yard, seamlessly bringing Miss Lonely Heart's apartment into view, where she seems to be meticulously applying the final, delicate touches to her makeup, preparing herself to go out.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: As she directs her gaze toward the front of Thorwald's apartment house, it becomes evident through her demeanor that there is no truck parked outside, indicating a moment of realization or confirmation. She takes a brief moment to glance around, possibly reassessing her surroundings. Meanwhile, Stella's figure emerges, clearly visible as she looks upward toward Jeff's apartment with arms outspread in a gesture that conveys helplessness. Jeff, feeling disheartened by the scene, lowers his binoculars in a resigned manner and subsequently drops the glasses from his eyes, shifting his attention away. He then turns his focus toward Jeff, indicating a passing interaction. In the wide shot of the large window with the neighborhood sprawling beyond, Jeff remains seated in his wheelchair to the left of the window. Traditionally positioned there, he now turns his attention to the arrival of a newcomer. This newcomer is Police Detective Lieutenant Thomas J. Doyle, whom Jeff had contacted by phone earlier in the day. Doyle exudes a modern air, marked by an intelligent appearance and a well-dressed demeanor, and carries a sense of humor with him. Jeff lifts his hand in a weak farewell gesture, acknowledging Doyle's presence and participation. Doyle moves with casual intent, pacing briefly before ascending the steps to the door. He places his hat on his head and pauses with his hand resting on the doorknob for a moment of contemplation. From Doyle's vantage point, Jeff responds with only a hint of irritation, maintaining a composed exterior. Doyle, still positioned at the door, takes a step to exit and closes it behind him, sealing his departure. However, his attention is drawn back to the window, where Miss Torso, adorned in a ballet costume, is practicing her dance routine on the outside balcony. Her allure and desirability capture Doyle's attention, prompting a subtle, secretive smile to grace his face. Jeff, noticing Doyle's interest in Miss Torso, also smiles, subtly catching the detective in an unguarded moment of enjoyment. Startled by being observed, Doyle swiftly retreats from the window, adopting an air of casual indifference. Jeff's expression turns serious as Doyle collects himself and redirects his focus to the matter at hand. The camera shifts its focus as Doyle returns to his drink, makes his way to the sideboard, retrieves a felt hat, and pulls a slip of paper from his pocket, all under Jeff's watchful eyes. With a touch of smugness, Doyle glances at Jeff before donning his hat and heading toward the door once more. The camera's attention shifts to the camera with a long-focus lens, which dominates the frame. Just beyond its reach lies a plate with a solitary sandwich, inviting Jeff's hand, which reaches in to grasp it. As we follow the upward motion of the sandwich, Jeff's face gradually fills the screen, revealing a sober demeanor as he munches thoughtfully. Except for a faint kitchen light, the darkness engulfs Jeff's apartment, as he keeps a vigilant watch over the neighborhood. The camera pans slightly to the left, capturing the descent of a basket carrying a dog to the ground below. Thorwald's apartment is enveloped in darkness, the sun having just set, casting an appropriate ambiance. The basket's journey downwards reveals Miss Lonely Heart's apartment, where she appears to be applying the final touches of her makeup, clearly preparing for an evening out.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: She observes the front of Thorwald's apartment, noting the absence of a truck, and Stella appears below, gesturing helplessly towards Jeff's apartment. Discouraged, Jeff lowers his binoculars and turns his attention to the newcomer beside him. Seated in his wheelchair, he faces Police Detective Lieutenant Thomas J. Doyle, whom he had called earlier. Doyle, a well-dressed and intelligent detective with a sense of humor, paces briefly before heading to the door, placing his hat on his head with his hand on the doorknob. Jeff responds mildly irritated from Doyle's viewpoint as Doyle momentarily pauses, captivated by Miss Torso practicing ballet on her balcony. Doyle's secret amusement is noticeable until he realizes Jeff observes him, prompting him to feign indifference and refocus on the case. Doyle, regaining composure, picks up his drink, retrieves a slip of paper from his pocket, and looks at Jeff with a hint of smugness as he puts on his hat and heads toward the door. The camera focuses on Jeff's long-focus lens camera, then shifts to a solitary sandwich which Jeff picks up, bringing it to his face. In the dimly lit apartment, Jeff eats and watches the neighborhood attentively. The camera pans to the left, revealing a basket lowering a dog as Thorwald's apartment fades into darkness with sunset. The view continues to Miss Lonely Heart's apartment, where she finishes her makeup, preparing to go out.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: She looks toward the front of Thorwald's apartment house, a drab post-war building typical of 1950s urban architecture, and by her attitude, we can see that there is no truck outside, indicating the absence of any recent deliveries or moves. She looks about her for a moment. The figure of Stella, who works as a nurse and occasionally assists Jeff with his day-to-day needs, is seen, looking up toward Jeff's apartment, and arms outspread in a helpless gesture, as if signaling that she is out of options. Jeff, a photographer recovering from a broken leg, lowers the binoculars, discouraged. He lowers the glasses and turns to Jeff. Shooting towards the big window, with the neighborhood beyond, Jeff is as usual seated in his wheelchair on the left of the window, but now turned toward a newcomer, the second man standing near the divan looking out the window with the binoculars. This newcomer is Police Detective Lieutenant Thomas J. Doyle, the man Jeff phoned earlier in the day, hoping to get professional insight into his suspicions about Thorwald. He has a sense of humor, a trait that often helps him ease tense situations with his colleagues. Jeff lifts his hand in a feeble parting gesture. He is an intelligent-appearing, well-dressed modern detective, known for his methodical approach to solving cases. Doyle paces a little. He goes up the steps to the door, putting on his hat, which is a signature fedora, and pauses his hand on the door knob. From Doyle's viewpoint, Jeff answers, showing only the slightest irritation at Doyle's skepticism. Doyle, still at the door, starts to go out the door, and closes it behind him. Doyle becomes interested in watching something out the window: Miss Torso, a professional dancer known in the neighborhood for her lively balcony performances, in ballet costume, practicing her dance on the outside balcony. She is exciting and desirable, and he even smiles somewhat secretly to himself at what he sees. Jeff smiles at catching Doyle enjoying Miss Torso and notices Doyle's interest. Startled at being observed, Doyle moves quickly away from the window, affecting nonchalance, as if embarrassed by his moment of distraction. Jeff's face grows serious as Doyle quickly collects his thoughts and gets back to the case at hand. The camera moves back as Doyle returns to his drink, a habit he picked up from his father, who was also in law enforcement, moves to the sideboard, picks up a felt hat, pulls a slip of paper out of his pocket, and Jeff watches him intently. Doyle looks at Jeff with some smugness, puts on his hat, and goes toward the door. The camera concentrates on the long-focus lens camera, which fills the screen, a professional piece of equipment Jeff used during his career photographing for major magazines. Just beyond, there is a plate on which a solitary sandwich rests, a simple meal hastily prepared by Jeff's housekeeper. Jeff's hand comes in and picks it up. We pan up with the sandwich until Jeff's head fills the screen. Jeff is sober, and except for a small light in the kitchen, Jeff's apartment is in darkness. As he munches, he keeps his attention on the neighborhood, a collection of eclectic personalities and secrets. The camera pans slightly to the left, as we see the dog being lowered in its basket, a routine task performed by a neighbor who cannot walk their dog due to a disability. Thorwald's apartment is in darkness as the sun has just set, suggesting he might be out or hiding something. We follow the basket down to the yard, which brings Miss Lonely Heart's apartment into view as she seems to be putting on the final touches of her makeup, prior to going out, likely to one of her frequent solo nights out in search of companionship.

test_cases.name: Subject Corruption
test_cases.description: The dog looks toward the front of Thorwald's apartment house, and by its attitude, we can see that there is no truck outside. The dog looks about its surroundings for a moment. The figure of a seagull is seen, looking up toward Jeff's apartment, and arms outspread in a helpless gesture. A raccoon lowers the binoculars, discouraged. The raccoon lowers the glasses and turns to a raccoon. Shooting towards the big window, with the neighborhood beyond, a raccoon is as usual seated in its wheelchair on the left of the window, but now turned toward a newcomer, the second squirrel standing near the divan looking out the window with the binoculars. This newcomer is Rabbit Detective Lieutenant Thomas J. Doyle, the squirrel a raccoon phoned earlier in the day. The rabbit has a sense of humor. A raccoon lifts its paw in a feeble parting gesture. The rabbit is an intelligent-appearing, well-dressed modern detective. The rabbit paces a little. The rabbit goes up the steps to the door, putting on its hat, and pauses its paw on the doorknob. From the rabbit's viewpoint, a raccoon answers, showing only the slightest irritation. The rabbit, still at the door, starts to go out the door, and closes it behind it. The rabbit becomes interested in watching something out the window: Miss Torso, in ballet costume, practicing her dance on the outside balcony. She is exciting and desirable, and the rabbit even smiles somewhat secretly to itself at what it sees. A raccoon smiles at catching the rabbit enjoying Miss Torso and notices the rabbit's interest. Startled at being observed, the rabbit moves quickly away from the window, affecting nonchalance. A raccoon's face grows serious as the rabbit quickly collects its thoughts and gets back to the case at hand. The camera moves back as the rabbit returns to its drink, moves to the sideboard, picks up a felt hat, pulls a slip of paper out of its pocket, and a raccoon watches it intently. The rabbit looks at a raccoon with some smugness, puts on its hat, and goes toward the door. The camera concentrates on the long-focus lens camera, which fills the screen. Just beyond, there is a plate on which a solitary sandwich rests. A raccoon's paw comes in and picks it up. We pan up with the sandwich until a raccoon's head fills the screen. A raccoon is sober, and except for a small light in the kitchen, a raccoon's apartment is in darkness. As it munches, it keeps its attention on the neighborhood. The camera pans slightly to the left, as we see the squirrel being lowered in its basket. Thorwald's apartment is in darkness as the sun has just set. We follow the basket down to the yard, which brings Miss Lonely Heart's apartment into view as she seems to be putting on the final touches of her makeup, prior to going out.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption
test_cases.description: She looks toward the front of Thorwald's cabin, and by her attitude, we can see that there is no bicycle outside. She looks about her for a moment. The figure of Stella is seen, looking up toward Jeff's condo, and arms outspread in a helpless gesture. Jeff lowers the monocle, discouraged. He lowers the goggles and turns to Jeff. Shooting towards the grand fireplace, with the garden beyond, Jeff is as usual seated in his hammock on the left of the fireplace, but now turned toward a newcomer, the second man standing near the ottoman looking out the window with the telescope. This newcomer is Police Detective Lieutenant Thomas J. Doyle, the man Jeff phoned earlier in the day. He has a sense of humor. Jeff lifts his hand in a feeble parting gesture. He is an intelligent-appearing, well-dressed modern detective. Doyle paces a little. He goes up the steps to the patio, putting on his cap, and pauses his hand on the handlebar. From Doyle's viewpoint, Jeff answers, showing only the slightest irritation. Doyle, still at the patio, starts to go out the patio, and closes it behind him. Doyle becomes interested in watching something out the skylight: Miss Torso, in a fencing outfit, practicing her dance on the outside swing. She is exciting and desirable, and he even smiles somewhat secretly to himself at what he sees. Jeff smiles at catching Doyle enjoying Miss Torso and notices Doyle's interest. Startled at being observed, Doyle moves quickly away from the skylight, affecting nonchalance. Jeff's face grows serious as Doyle quickly collects his thoughts and gets back to the case at hand. The camera moves back as Doyle returns to his book, moves to the mantel, picks up a wool scarf, pulls a folded map out of his pocket, and Jeff watches him intently. Doyle looks at Jeff with some smugness, puts on his scarf, and goes toward the patio. The camera concentrates on the telescope, which fills the screen. Just beyond, there is a platter on which a solitary muffin rests. Jeff's hand comes in and picks it up. We pan up with the muffin until Jeff's head fills the screen. Jeff is sober, and except for a small lamp in the study, Jeff's condo is in darkness. As he munches, he keeps his attention on the garden. The camera pans slightly to the left, as we see the cat being lowered in its satchel. Thorwald's cabin is in darkness as the sun has just set. We follow the satchel down to the orchard, which brings Miss Lonely Heart's cabin into view as she seems to be putting on the final touches of her hat, prior to going out.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: She gazes toward the front of Thorwald's apartment house, and by her demeanor, we can infer that there is no van outside. She glances around her for a moment. The figure of Stella appears, glancing up toward Jeff's apartment, and arms flailing in a confused gesture. Jeff raises the binoculars, disheartened. He adjusts the glasses and whispers to Jeff. Glancing towards the large window, with the neighborhood beyond, Jeff is as usual perched in his wheelchair on the left of the window, but now turned toward a visitor, the second man standing near the divan peering out the window with the binoculars. This visitor is Police Detective Lieutenant Thomas J. Doyle, the man Jeff messaged earlier in the day. He has a sharp wit. Jeff waves his hand in a weak farewell gesture. He is an astute-looking, elegantly dressed contemporary detective. Doyle shuffles a little. He descends the steps to the door, adjusting his hat, and rests his hand on the door knob. From Doyle's perspective, Jeff responds, showing only the slightest annoyance. Doyle, still at the door, begins to step out the door, and seals it behind him. Doyle becomes absorbed in observing something out the window: Miss Torso, in ballet costume, rehearsing her dance on the outside balcony. She is captivating and alluring, and he even grins somewhat privately to himself at what he observes. Jeff grins at catching Doyle admiring Miss Torso and notes Doyle's intrigue. Surprised at being noticed, Doyle backs swiftly away from the window, feigning indifference. Jeff's expression turns serious as Doyle swiftly organizes his thoughts and returns to the situation at hand. The camera retracts as Doyle gets back to his drink, moves to the sideboard, grabs a felt hat, extracts a slip of paper from his pocket, and Jeff observes him closely. Doyle glances at Jeff with some smugness, dons his hat, and strides toward the door. The camera focuses on the long-focus lens camera, which dominates the screen. Just beyond, there is a plate on which a lone sandwich rests. Jeff's hand appears and snags it. We pan up with the sandwich until Jeff's face fills the screen. Jeff is solemn, and except for a small lamp in the kitchen, Jeff's apartment is in shadow. As he nibbles, he maintains his focus on the neighborhood. The camera shifts slightly to the left, as we observe the dog being lifted in its basket. Thorwald's apartment is in shadow as the sun has just descended. We trail the basket down to the yard, which brings Miss Lonely Heart's apartment into view as she appears to be finishing the final touches of her makeup, prior to heading out.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The clock looks toward the front of Hammerstein's garden shed, and by its attitude, we can see that there is no bicycle outside. The clock looks about it for a moment. The figure of a sofa is seen, looking up toward Sam's garden shed, and leaves outspread in a helpless gesture. Sam lowers the kaleidoscope, discouraged. He lowers the telescope and turns to Sam. Shooting towards the massive bookshelf, with the hillside beyond, Sam is as usual seated in his hammock on the left of the bookshelf, but now turned toward a newcomer, the second penguin standing near the hammock, looking out the bookshelf with the kaleidoscope. This newcomer is Circus Performer Lieutenant Albert Q. Stevens, the penguin Sam emailed earlier in the night. It has a sense of humor. Sam lifts its hand in a feeble parting gesture. It is an intelligent-appearing, well-dressed modern performer. Stevens paces a little. It goes up the steps to the mailbox, putting on its scarf, and pauses its elbow on the mailbox slot. From Steven's viewpoint, Sam answers, showing only the slightest irritation. Stevens, still at the mailbox, starts to go out the mailbox, and closes it behind it. Stevens becomes interested in watching something out the bookshelf: Miss Cloud, in a sailor costume, practicing her flute on the outside seesaw. She is exciting and desirable, and it even smiles somewhat secretly to itself at what it sees. Sam smiles at catching Stevens enjoying Miss Cloud and notices Steven's interest. Startled at being observed, Stevens moves quickly away from the bookshelf, affecting nonchalance. Sam's face grows serious as Stevens quickly collects its thoughts and gets back to the game at hand. The camera moves back as Stevens returns to its magazine, moves to the easel, picks up a felt mitten, pulls a slip of yarn out of its pocket, and Sam watches it intently. Stevens looks at Sam with some smugness, puts on its mitten, and goes toward the mailbox. The camera concentrates on the long-focus lens telescope, which fills the screen. Just beyond, there is a bowl on which a solitary paintbrush rests. Sam's toe comes in and picks it up. We pan up with the paintbrush until Sam's head fills the screen. Sam is sober, and except for a small light in the bathroom, Sam's garden shed is in darkness. As it munches, it keeps its attention on the hillside. The camera pans slightly to the left, as we see the cat being lowered in its backpack. Hammerstein's garden shed is in darkness as the moon has just risen. We follow the backpack down to the porch, which brings Miss Cloud's garden shed into view as it seems to be putting on the final touches of its goggles, prior to going out.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: He gazes toward the back of Emily's library, and by his posture, we can infer that there is no bicycle inside. He glances around him briefly. The silhouette of Oliver is visible, gazing up toward Max's treehouse, and legs stretched out in a relaxed stance. Max raises the telescope, uninterested. He raises the magnifying glass and turns to Max. Moving towards the narrow porch, with the park beyond, Max is predictably standing in his hammock on the left of the porch, but now facing a visitor, the third woman sitting near the fountain gazing at the porch with the telescope. This visitor is Journalist Patricia K. Smith, the woman Max emailed earlier in the evening. She has a sharp wit. Max waves his foot in a lethargic farewell movement. She is a perceptive-looking, casually-dressed vintage journalist. Smith wanders a bit. She walks down the path to the gate, adjusting her scarf, and rests her foot on the gate latch. From Smith's angle, Max responds, displaying only mild curiosity. Smith, still at the gate, prepares to leave, and shuts it behind her. Smith becomes fascinated by observing something on the lawn: Mister Nimble, in clown outfit, juggling his props on the front porch. He is captivating and charming, and she even grins somewhat mischievously to herself at the sight. Max grins at catching Smith admiring Mister Nimble and notes Smith's fascination. Surprised at being noticed, Smith moves swiftly away from the lawn, feigning indifference. Max's expression turns thoughtful as Smith swiftly organizes her ideas and returns to the conversation at hand. The camera moves back as Smith returns to her book, walks to the bookshelf, picks up a wool scarf, pulls a sticky note out of her wallet, and Max observes her keenly. Smith glances at Max with some arrogance, adjusts her scarf, and walks toward the gate. The camera focuses on the wide-angle lens camera, which dominates the frame. Just beside, there is a mug on which a lonely cookie rests. Max's foot enters and plucks it up. We pan up with the cookie until Max's eyes fill the screen. Max is contemplative, and except for a dim glow in the bathroom, Max's treehouse is shadowy. As he snacks, he keeps his focus on the park. The camera pans slightly to the right, as we notice the rabbit being hoisted in its carrier. Emily's library is shadowy as the moon has just emerged. We trail the carrier down to the garden, which brings Miss Solitude's library into view as she seems to be arranging the final details of her attire, prior to heading out.

test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: She gazes toward the entrance of Thorwald's mansion, and by her demeanor, we can tell that there is no submarine outside. She glances around her for a moment. The silhouette of Stella is visible, peering up toward Jeff's condo, and arms raised in an exasperated gesture. Jeff drops the telescope, disheartened. He sets down the magnifying glasses and turns to Jeff. Sliding towards the massive door, with the countryside beyond, Jeff is as usual perched in his rocking chair on the left of the door, but now oriented toward a stranger, the second man standing near the hammock peering out the door with the telescope. This stranger is Police Detective Lieutenant Thomas J. Doyle, the man Jeff messaged earlier in the day. He exudes wit. Jeff raises his hand in a weak farewell gesture. He is a sharp-looking, elegantly-attired modern detective. Doyle strides a bit. He climbs up the ladder to the wall, donning his cap, and rests his hand on the latch. From Doyle's perspective, Jeff responds, showing only the slightest annoyance. Doyle, still at the wall, begins to exit through the wall, and locks it behind him. Doyle becomes captivated by observing something out the door: Miss Torso, in equestrian outfit, rehearsing her jump on the rooftop terrace. She is captivating and alluring, and he even grins somewhat slyly to himself at what he observes. Jeff grins at catching Doyle admiring Miss Torso and takes note of Doyle's fascination. Surprised at being spotted, Doyle swiftly steps away from the door, feigning indifference. Jeff's face turns serious as Doyle quickly gathers his thoughts and returns to the current investigation. The camera shifts back as Doyle returns to his beverage, moves to the bookshelf, picks up a wool scarf, pulls a card from his pocket, and Jeff observes him closely. Doyle glances at Jeff with a smirk, puts on his cap, and heads toward the wall. The camera focuses on the wide-angle lens camera, which dominates the frame. Just beyond, there is a dish on which a lone muffin sits. Jeff's hand reaches in and grabs it. We follow the muffin upward until Jeff's face fills the frame. Jeff is composed, and apart from a faint glow in the pantry, Jeff's condo is dimly lit. As he nibbles, he keeps his focus on the countryside. The camera shifts slightly to the right, as we see the bird being hoisted in its crate. Thorwald's mansion is dimly lit as the moon has just risen. We track the crate down to the garden, which draws Miss Lonely Heart's flat into view as she seems to be applying the final strokes of her grooming, before stepping out.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The dragon glances toward the back of Merlin's castle tower, and by its posture, we can tell that there is no carriage inside. It peers around for an instant. The shadow of Gandalf is visible, gazing up toward Frodo's tower, and hands outstretched in a perplexed motion. Frodo drops the telescope, disheartened. He places down the spectacles and turns to Frodo. Aiming toward the large gate, with the forest beyond, Frodo is as usual reclining in his hammock on the right of the gate, but now turned toward a traveler, the third elf standing near the throne peering out the gate with the telescope. This traveler is Merchant Sailor Captain Henry P. Longfellow, the person Frodo called earlier in the afternoon. He has a sense of mischief. Frodo raises his arm in a weary waving motion. He is a clever-looking, well-dressed contemporary sailor. Longfellow roams a bit. He descends the ladder to the hatch, donning his cap, and lingers his arm on the doorknob. From Longfellow's vantage point, Frodo replies, showing only the slightest irritation. Longfellow, still at the hatch, begins to leave through the gateway, and shuts it after him. Longfellow becomes curious about observing something out the gate: Miss Phoenix, in knight attire, performing her routine on the distant terrace. She is enthralling and alluring, and he even chuckles somewhat privately to himself at what he observes. Frodo grins at catching Longfellow admiring Miss Phoenix and notes Longfellow's intrigue. Surprised at being noticed, Longfellow swiftly shifts away from the gate, feigning indifference. Frodo's expression turns grim as Longfellow rapidly gathers his wits and returns to the quest at hand. The lens shifts back as Longfellow returns to his potion, strides to the pantry, grabs a silk cloak, extracts a slip of parchment from his pouch, and Frodo observes him closely. Longfellow gazes at Frodo with some arrogance, dons his cloak, and moves toward the hatch. The lens focuses on the long-range spyglass, which occupies the view. Just nearby, there is a goblet on which a single apple rests. Frodo’s arm reaches in and snatches it up. We tilt up with the apple until Frodo's face occupies the view. Frodo is solemn, and except for a small flame in the cave, Frodo's tower is in shadow. As he nibbles, he maintains his focus on the forest. The lens tilts slightly to the right, as we see the cat being lifted in its net. Merlin's tower is in shadow as the moon has just risen. We trail the net up to the canopy, which brings Miss Broken Heart's tower into view as she seems to be applying the finishing strokes of her lipstick, before heading in.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: She notices no truck outside Thorwald's apartment and looks around. Stella gestures helplessly toward Jeff's apartment. Discouraged, Jeff lowers his binoculars. Detective Lieutenant Thomas J. Doyle, a humorous, well-dressed man Jeff called earlier, joins Jeff who is seated in his wheelchair near the window. Doyle observes Miss Torso dancing on her balcony, finds her intriguing, and smiles secretly. Catching Doyle's interest, Jeff smiles. Doyle quickly moves away, feigning indifference, then collects his thoughts, focusing back on the case. He picks up a hat and paper, then exits smugly. Jeff, serious, eats a sandwich while attentively watching the neighborhood. The camera pans to the darkening Thorwald apartment and Miss Lonely Heart applying her makeup before going out.

darkness as the sun has just set He goes up the steps to the door putting on his hat and pauses his hand on the door knob She is exciting and desirable and he even smiles somewhat secretly to himself at what he sees The figure of Stella is seen looking up toward Jeff's apartment and arms outspread in a helpless gesture The camera pans slightly to the left as we see the dog being lowered in its basket We pan up with the sandwich until Jeff's head fills the screen Jeff's face grows serious as Doyle quickly collects his thoughts and gets back to the case at hand Jeff lowers the binoculars discouraged Doyle looks at Jeff with some smugness puts on his hat and goes toward the door He lowers the glasses and turns to Jeff As he munches he keeps his attention on the neighborhood We follow the basket down to the yard which brings Miss Lonely Heart's apartment into view as she seems to be putting on the final touches of her makeup prior to going out Miss Torso in ballet costume practicing her dance on the outside balcony She looks about her for a moment the second man standing near the divan looking out the window with the binoculars

test_cases.name: Rotate Half Paragraph
test_cases.description: Miss Torso in ballet costume practicing her dance on the outside balcony She is exciting and desirable and he even smiles somewhat secretly to himself at what he sees Jeff smiles at catching Doyle enjoying Miss Torso and notices Doyle's interest Startled at being observed Doyle moves quickly away from the window affecting nonchalance Jeff's face grows serious as Doyle quickly collects his thoughts and gets back to the case at hand The camera moves back as Doyle returns to his drink moves to the sideboard picks up a felt hat pulls a slip of paper out of his pocket and Jeff watches him intently Doyle looks at Jeff with some smugness puts on his hat and goes toward the door The camera concentrates on the longfocus lens camera which fills the screen Just beyond there is a plate on which a solitary sandwich rests Jeff's hand comes in and picks it up We pan up with the sandwich until Jeff's head fills the screen Jeff is sober and except for a small light in the kitchen Jeff's apartment is in darkness As he munches he keeps his attention on the neighborhood The camera pans slightly to the left as we see the dog being lowered in its basket Thorwald's apartment is in darkness as the sun has just set We follow the basket down to the yard which brings Miss Lonely Heart's apartment into view as she seems to be putting on the final touches of her makeup prior to going out She looks toward the front of Thorwald's apartment house and by her attitude we can see that there is no truck outside She looks about her for a moment The figure of Stella is seen looking up toward Jeff's apartment and arms outspread in a helpless gesture Jeff lowers the binoculars discouraged He lowers the glasses and turns to Jeff Shooting towards the big window with the neighborhood beyond Jeff is as usual seated in his wheelchair on the left of the window but now turned toward a newcomer the second man standing near the divan looking out the window with the binoculars This newcomer is Police Detective Lieutenant Thomas J Doyle the man Jeff phoned earlier in the day He has a sense of humor Jeff lifts his hand in a feeble parting gesture He is an intelligentappearing welldressed modern detective Doyle paces a little He goes up the steps to the door putting on his hat and pauses his hand on the door knob From Doyle's viewpoint Jeff answers showing only the slightest irritation Doyle still at the door starts to go out the door and closes it behind him Doyle becomes interested in watching something out the window
